keyTakeAways: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) faces a $1.7 billion funding gap through 2029, primarily due to reduced foreign aid from major donors.
The World Health Organization (WHO) and the Gates Foundation are leading the GPEI, which is central to global polio eradication efforts.
Reduced funding, especially from the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom, is undermining critical polio vaccination and surveillance activities.
The GPEI plans to prioritize high-risk areas like Afghanistan and Pakistan, where wild polio cases have been reported, and adopt fractional dosing to stretch vaccine supplies.
Vaccine-derived polio has been reported in 149 cases across countries, including Nigeria, highlighting risks in areas with low vaccination coverage.
Despite the funding shortfall, experts maintain that eradication remains feasible with continued global commitment.
The persistence of polio in Afghanistan and Pakistan is due to asymptomatic transmission and limited vaccination access, making surveillance and outreach vital.
Cases of both wild and vaccine-derived polio have declined since 2024, showing progress despite funding challenges.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI), led by the World Health Organization and the Gates Foundation, faces a $1.7 billion funding shortfall through 2029 due to reduced foreign aid from key donors, especially the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom. This financial strain threatens critical polio eradication activities, with the WHO’s director Jamal Ahmed warning that essential programs may not proceed. In response, the GPEI will focus resources on high-risk areas like Afghanistan and Pakistan, where wild polio cases have been reported, and adopt strategies such as fractional dosing to conserve vaccine supplies. The persistence of polio in these regions is due to asymptomatic transmission and low vaccination access, while vaccine-derived polio cases have also been recorded in countries like Nigeria. Despite the funding crisis, experts maintain that eradication remains achievable with sustained global commitment.
title: WHO warns $1.7bn funding shortfall threatens polio eradication efforts
